https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/77567/ : SUCCESS
This repository is phosphor-health-monitor, so there is no need for this prefix.
Acknowledged
Thanks for review.
Would it be possible to use the strings from the Metrics.Value for these?  I understand these are likely coming from JSON but it seems like those strings could still be valid options?
We don't have these values defined in Metrics.Value. It has paths with / delimiters, for example cpu/user, memory/free, etc.
Maybe the JSON should match those then? ;)
Done
Prefer lowercase for namespaces (just json).
Done
This is this namespace ... what is this accomplishing?
Done
This isn't obvious what this is for.
Currently health monitor only has logic for upper thresholds, so just defining the default constexpr for that.
Done
Some comments on the purpose of these would be nice.
Done
Honestly, I'd rather just have the strings embedded here if this is the only use of them.  Otherwise there is a lot of indirection.
Acknowledged
Is it possible to forward declare this and then move the implementation to the bottom and/or another file?
Sorry, i tried but it doesn't seem to work.
Done
Acknowledged

Suggest moving down to 187.  No need to forward declare.

Also `ThresholdConfig config{};` or `auto config = ThresholdConfig();`.  No need to repeat yourself.
Acknowledged
Don't duplicate this search from 179.  Save it in a local.
`const auto&` to avoid a copy?
Acknowledged
thresholdType is just an enum type, do we really need a reference here?
Discussed with @Patrick, so no change needed on this.

How do we know that these `.value` calls return the appropriate type for the storage location?  Is there some magic where nlohmann::json gives a `json` type back for the `value` function and the conversion constructor calls a `get<Type>` under the covers that throws?
Discussed with @Patrick and this is automatically being handled.

Does the existing code return an empty json?  This seems dangerous because it means that mistakes in config changes are not quickly detected (via a std::terminate of uncaught exception) and instead someone would have to notice the Metrics missing or this particular journal entry (much less likely).

This is what existing code does https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-health-monitor/blob/master/healthMonitor.cpp#L581.

But now we have changed the flow. We are not mandating the json file as default config is in code. If platform wants to over-ride only then they will provide the json file. Hence i have marked the message a warning and returned empty json.

Discussed with Patrick on this.
1. Changed the warning message to info in case json file is not found since now the default config is in code.
2. Changed parse API to throw exception in case parsing fails and fail fast rather than just continuing.
Why false/is_discarded here?  Can't we throw an exception and fail-fast?
This is what we have in existing code https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-health-monitor/blob/master/healthMonitor.cpp#L581. We can just break if there are errors. Please let me know.
Done

`std::to_underlying(metricType)`  (replace all `int` casts in the logging code)

At one point I considered adding direct support in lg2 for sdbusplus enumerations but I don't think I ever implemented it.
Acknowledged
Suggest some sort of typedef for this.  You've ended up repeating this type 3 times now (return in hpp, return in cpp, here).
Acknowledged
Don't repeat the same search multiple times.
Acknowledged
Not necessary.
Done
Not necessary.
Done
Is there a `decltype(...)` we can use to get this from the generated code from Threshold?
No this type doesn't exist in the generated code since it has a config for the threshold as well.
Default initializers?
We already have default values being used when we read the json config (in case a value doesn't exist), hence don't see a need to specify it again here.
unordered_map?
Discussed with Patrick and will continue to use map since this is a small container size and using unordered_map will need a hash function specification.
I don't think it is possible for phosphor-health-monitor to be a subproject, so just make this `auto`, which it should be by default in the options.  (I think you can drop this)
Acknowledged
`if get_option('tests').allowed()` -- more modern option
Acknowledged

Add variables for each of these in the top level rather than repeating.  You might add something like `base_deps = [ ... ]` also.

```
phosphor_logging_dep =
phosphor_dbus_interfaces_dep =
sdbusplus_dep =
nlohmann_json_dep =
```

I am getting an error when using base_deps in test/meson.build.

How to make them accessible in other meson.build files?
I tried it again but i still see the same error. Can you please point me to specific examples in openbmc repo which does this inclusion from top level meson file in subdir meson files?

Pretty much every one should be doing it this way.  Here is one particular example.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/972dd4f62890cf676c80270636ad63a7ca9a590a/test/meson.build#L47
Done
Addressed comments as per our discussion,
Addressed your comments.

`get<1>`


Shouldn't both of these be `get<Type>`, `get<Bound>` in order to avoid this kind of bug?
Done

I don't like that we're modifying the "default" config.  I would expect this to have stayed a constant.  I could see someone wanting to, based on a signal(*), reload the config, which you've made difficult.  Suggest making a copy of the json and modifying that.

(*) ie. `systemctl reload phosphor-health-monitor.service`.
Done
Let's make a using alias for this type.
Done
`const std::string&` ?
Done

Here is the problem... you need to move this down.  Tests should be near the end of the file.

(What's happening is that you're including the file before the dependency variables have been defined)
Done
Did you intentionally move this?
Yes. Its a good debug in case of a test case failure.
